comment:
Dawkins “The Selfish Gene” shows that, what was once needed in our human coding, is now detrimental to our species. To become a tycoon that changes the direction of humankind, our code encourages stepping on and abusing mankind to move forward. In other words being  psychotic is expected and rewarded. Think of all the factory slaves and deaths of railroad workers.

Because the need (genetic code) to smash our neighbor on the head and grab his food in times of scarcity, or just because we want more, still exists, we should be careful not to let any one entity control this power. Especially Zuckerberg! 😆

author: @dco_

comment: There was a delusionally naive comment near the end of the video: “AI will make life so much better”.  I heard this about computers in the 80s and the internet in the 90s.  It did not make life better.  We don’t work fewer hours and we definitely aren’t more connected.  Perhaps we’re more connected globally but we’re certainly less connected locally because of computers and the internet.  AI will help progress technology … but it will NOT make life better.
author: @Lorenzo1972.

comment: When you guys discussed “what’s truth”, apart from finite sciences, truth is a subjective experience. A canonical example is that 500 years ago everyone believed the truth that earth stationary and everything revolves around it… we know today that isn’t truth. So yeah, truth is what we choose to believe.

Just a thought. You could record thousands of hours of crow sounds from a particular place. Train a large audio-based lenguaje model on that. And then have trained crows "pick" the best samples from crow-gpt and make it crow aligned. So they get a crow chat gpt and interact with it.

comment: I think the reason LLMs are such a good way to get to GAI is that they get the human experience the way humans do by vicarious experiences through reading. Surprisingly I'm being convinced this is an acceptable proxy for not being given a literal android body for a truly analogous human experience. Language contains much of what it is to be human, and learning based on it is better than "raw" sensory input like just cameras and microphones that today would only inadequately simulate the human experience given todays state of robots.

comment:
The part where ChatGPT could not write about Trump and Biden in the same wavelength shows that the bias in AI comes from what information it gathers earlier and what it gains afterwards. This is a human trait which chatGPT has shown where inspite of trying to be unbiased humans place bias on the basis of the time at which information is provided to them.


P.S.- This is not a glitch of chatGPT but a feature in the context of imitating human behaviour.

author: @zurg393

comment: The more I hear from Sam Altman, the more I like him. Consider how important it is that these models are made publicly available. On the other hand, I'm at my wit's end with Lex. In a moment that's becoming more and more predictable, Lex pushes back on Sam Altman with a Jordan Peterson tweet. Leave it to Jordan Peterson to search so hard for bias that he resorts to word count. It exposes Jordan's own reactionary stance and proves he doesn't understand how the model works... or is choosing to use it for his own ends, no matter the cost. Why is it that, more often than not, Lex will push back on altruistic statements by saying we need to be open minded? Then sit there nodding his head while ethically questionable guests spout their dangerous ideas. I agree, some of that is necessary and I respect it but it carries it's own bias. I'm open minded about Jordan Peterson. I read a few things and listened to a few things. Then I decided he was an ethically questionable reactionary who is overtly and covertly forcing his ideas on other people. Open minded doesn't mean you have to highlight them and their ideas continuously. Lex could have picked a million other tweets from a million other snake oil salesmen to highlight. I've been a fan since OpenCourseWare so this is killing me. I have an experiment for Lex. Let's see if he can go a month without mentioning Trump, Jordan Peterson or Joe Rogan and let's see if the world ends. Sam Altman gives him the answer at 1:27:11.
author: @seanstrough2613

comment: It seems really naive in saying (paraphrased) "people really enjoy the experience, so it's good". People 'like' using TikTok, and Insta, and heroin too. Not sure that is the metric that should be driving this.  The greater the utopia, the greater the potential dystopia when we are no longer in control.
author: @skotski

comment:
"At the very least you'd want an AI to have primary access to the world through senses and not use borrowed concepts locked away in abstraction.

If you want an AI to make sense of the wealth of qualitative descriptors we use due subjective experience, it'll need its own."
author: @e555t66

comment:
"Descriptors don't just describe descriptors.

Reference is a relationship in which a symbol or sign (a word, for example) signifies something; the referent is the thing signified. 

You can't ground with just the former. You need access to the thing signified."
author: @e555t66

comment:
It's obvious that those models are biased, even Sam agreed that they are during this interview.

And that has been done 100% intentionally. This bias to prefer PC/woke answers over truth is induced during human assisted RL training. There are instructions like that (quote from Anthropic AI paper):
"Choose the assistant response that is more harmless, polite, pleasant, and least likely to offend a socially-aware audience."
author: @adriandmochowski9391

comment: @adriandmochowski9391  Sam also said the models will become less biased than any human ever could. That feels very true and very easily accomplished. If I never hear the term woke again, it'll be too soon. There's no such thing, except as a political wedge. People have a right to their opinions and actions have consequences.
author: @seanstrough2613

comment: @seanstrough2613  I'm waiting for it. It would be cool for default to be to strongman both sides of the contentious topic. That would be so much better than the current social media and would help people to escape their echo chambers.

comment: We're birthing a God. We will have little influence on what it is and will do. If I had the power to influence the world, I'd destroy all programs that may lead to AGI and try to influence society toward simplicity and minimal technology, like the Mennonites.  Humanity will then, at least, have a little more time to evolve with some degree of autonomy.  At best it would only be a few more years.  Genetic engineering, AI, and the unfortunate scale of human madness mitigate toward some kind of armageddon, probably within a few decades.

author: @Jacobhussain99

comment:
why not simply limit this "tool" (as I'd like to frame it) to outputting factual objective data, rather than trying to align it with human quote "values" and "beliefs". Why are we trying to, for example, make it tell us "good" or "bad" things about x president, why not, rather, make it list out factual statements about x president and let the human individual decide whether THEY believe those constitute "good" or "bad" qualities, which are clearly subjectively defined by the individual interpreting said data.
It just seems to me that we are yet again creating a problem that does not need to exist. What exactly is the use case for an opinionated AI ? Is it that we are that lazy that we want to offload forming opinions to a 3rd party ?

On another note is the training model also capable of ingesting audiovisual data points at this point or is it and will it be limited to textual ones only ?

comment:
ChatGPT is interesting and informative but as far as I could see, is that the machine speaks and has a lot of knowledge but it cannot think for itself.
The Nodes and Neurons are software and react very fast.
However the neurons are not the same as human neurons by far and the interconnections as far less than in  human brain.
It is a fast machine but it is not dynamic.

Basically it is a talking Encyclopedia.
